TITLE 42—THE PUBLIC HEALTH AND WELFARE, CHAPTER 85—AIR POLLUTION PREVENTION AND CONTROL, SUBCHAPTER VI—STRATOSPHERIC OZONE PROTECTION, §7671h. Servicing of motor vehicle air conditioners: (a) Regulations Within 1 year after November 15, 1990, the Administrator shall promulgate regulations in accordance with this section establishing standards and requirements regarding the servicing of motor vehicle air conditioners. (b) Definitions As used in this section— (1) The term "refrigerant" means any class I or class II substance used in a motor vehicle air conditioner. Effective 5 years after November 15, 1990, the term "refrigerant" shall also include any substitute substance. (2)(A) The term "approved refrigerant recycling equipment" means equipment certified by the Administrator (or an independent standards testing organization approved by the Administrator) to meet the standards established by the Administrator and applicable to equipment for the extraction and reclamation of refrigerant from motor vehicle air conditioners. Such standards shall, at a minimum, be at least as stringent as the standards of the Society of Automotive Engineers in effect as of November 15, 1990, and applicable to such equipment (SAE standard J–1990). (B) Equipment purchased before the proposal of regulations under this section shall be considered certified if it is substantially identical to equipment certified as provided in subparagraph (A). (3) The term "properly using" means, with respect to approved refrigerant recycling equipment, using such equipment in conformity with standards established by the Administrator and applicable to the use of such equipment. Such standards shall, at a minimum, be at least as stringent as the standards of the Society of Automotive Engineers in effect as of November 15, 1990, and applicable to the use of such equipment (SAE standard J–1989). (4) The term "properly trained and certified" means training and certification in the proper use of approved refrigerant recycling equipment for motor vehicle air conditioners in conformity with standards established by the Administrator and applicable to the performance of service on motor vehicle air conditioners. Such standards shall, at a minimum, be at least as stringent as specified, as of November 15, 1990, in SAE standard J–1989 under the certification program of the National Institute for Automotive Service Excellence (ASE) or under a similar program such as the training and certification program of the Mobile Air Conditioning Society (MACS). (c) Servicing motor vehicle air conditioners Effective January 1, 1992, no person repairing or servicing motor vehicles for consideration may perform any service on a motor vehicle air conditioner involving the refrigerant for such air conditioner without properly using approved refrigerant recycling equipment and no such person may perform such service unless such person has been properly trained and certified. The requirements of the previous sentence shall not apply until January 1, 1993 in the case of a person repairing or servicing motor vehicles for consideration at an entity which performed service on fewer than 100 motor vehicle air conditioners during calendar year 1990 and if such person so certifies, pursuant to subsection (d)(2), to the Administrator by January 1, 1992. (d) Certification (1) Effective 2 years after November 15, 1990, each person performing service on motor vehicle air conditioners for consideration shall certify to the Administrator either— (A) that such person has acquired, and is properly using, approved refrigerant recycling equipment in service on motor vehicle air conditioners involving refrigerant and that each individual authorized by such person to perform such service is properly trained and certified; or (B) that such person is performing such service at an entity which serviced fewer than 100 motor vehicle air conditioners in 1991. (2) Effective January 1, 1993, each person who certified under paragraph (1)(B) shall submit a certification under paragraph (1)(A). (3) Each certification under this subsection shall contain the name and address of the person certifying under this subsection and the serial number of each unit of approved recycling equipment acquired by such person and shall be signed and attested by the owner or another responsible officer. Certifications under paragraph (1)(A) may be made by submitting the required information to the Administrator on a standard form provided by the manufacturer of certified refrigerant recycling equipment. (e) Small containers of class I or class II substances Effective 2 years after November 15, 1990, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell or distribute, or offer for sale or distribution, in interstate commerce to any person (other than a person performing service for consideration on motor vehicle air-conditioning systems in compliance with this section) any class I or class II substance that is suitable for use as a refrigerant in a motor vehicle air-conditioning system and that is in a container which contains less than 20 pounds of such refrigerant.

TITLE 15—COMMERCE AND TRADE, CHAPTER 62—CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSION PROTECTION AND ABUSE RELIEF, , §3608. Judicial determinations respecting unconscionable leases: (a) Lease characteristics; authorization by unit owners; conditions precedent to action Cooperative and condominium unit owners through the unit owners' association may bring an action seeking a judicial determination that a lease or leases, or portions thereof, were unconscionable at the time they were made. An action may be brought under this section if each such lease has all of the following characteristics: (1) it was made in connection with a cooperative or condominium project; (2) it was entered into while the cooperative or condominium owners' association was controlled by the developer either through special developer control or because the developer held a majority of the votes in the owners' association; (3) it had to be accepted or ratified by purchasers or through the unit owners' association as a condition of purchase of a unit in the cooperative or condominium project; (4) it is for a period of more than twenty-one years or is for a period of less than twenty-one years but contains automatic renewal provisions for a period of more than twenty-one years; (5) it contains an automatic rent increase clause; and (6) it was entered into prior to June 4, 1975. Such action must be authorized by the cooperative or condominium unit owners through a vote of not less than two-thirds of the owners of the units other than units owned by the developer or an affiliate of the developer, and may be brought by the cooperative or condominium unit owners through the units owners' association. Prior to instituting such action, the cooperative or condominium unit owners must, through a vote of not less than two-thirds of the owners of the units other than units owned by the developer or an affiliate of the developer, agree to enter into negotiation with the lessor and must seek through such negotiation to eliminate or modify any lease terms that are alleged to be unconscionable; if an agreement is not reached in ninety days from the date on which the authorizing vote was taken, the unit owners may authorize an action after following the procedure specified in the preceding sentence. (b) Presumption of unconscionability; rebuttal A rebuttal presumption of unconscionability exists if it is established that, in addition to the characteristics set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the lease— (1) creates a lien subjecting any unit to foreclosure for failure to make payments; (2) contains provisions requiring either the cooperative or condominium unit owners or the cooperative or condominium association as lessees to assume all or substantially all obligations and liabilities associated with the maintenance, management and use of the leased property, in addition to the obligation to make lease payments; (3) contains an automatic rent increase clause without establishing a specific maximum lease payment; and (4) requires an annual rental which exceeds 25 per centum of the appraised value of the leased property as improved: Provided, That, for purposes of this paragraph "annual rental" means the amount due during the first twelve months of the lease for all units, regardless of whether such units were occupied or sold during that period, and "appraised value" means the appraised value placed upon the leased property the first tax year after the sale of a unit in the condominium or after the sale of a membership or share interest in the cooperative association to a party who is not an affiliate of the developer. Once the rebuttable presumption is established, the court, in making its finding, shall consider the lease or portion of the lease to be unconscionable unless proven otherwise by the preponderance of the evidence to the contrary. (c) Presentation of evidence after finding of unconscionability Whenever it is claimed, or appears to the court, that a lease or any portion thereof is, or may have been, unconscionable at the time it was made, the parties shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present evidence at least as to– (1) the commercial setting of the negotiations; (2) whether a party has knowingly taken advantage of the inability of the other party reasonably to protect his interests; (3) the effect and purpose of the lease or portion of the lease or portion thereof, including its relationship to other contracts between the association, the unit owners and the developer or an affiliate of the developer; and (4) the disparity between the amount charged under the lease and the value of the real estate subject to the lease measured by the price at which similar real estate was readily obtainable in similar transactions. (d) Remedial relief; matters considered; attorneys' fees Upon finding that any lease, or portion thereof, is unconscionable, the court shall exercise its authority to grant remedial relief as necessary to avoid an unconscionable result, taking into consideration the economic value of the lease. Such relief may include, but shall not be limited to rescission, reformation, restitution, the award of damages and reasonable attorney fees and court costs. A defendant may recover reasonable attorneys' fees if the court determines that the cause of action filed by the plantiff 1 is frivolous, malicious, or lacking in substantial merit. (e) Actions allowed after termination of special developer control Nothing in this section may be construed to authorize the bringing of an action by cooperative and condominium unit owners' association, seeking a judicial determination that a lease or leases, or portions thereof, are unconscionable, where such unit owners or a unit owners' association representing them has, after the termination of special developer control, reached an agreement with a holder of such lease or leases which either— (1) sets forth the terms and conditions under which such lease or leases is or shall be purchased by such unit owners or associations; or (2) reforms any clause in the lease which contained an automatic rent increase clause, unless such agreement was entered into when the leaseholder or his affiliate held a majority of the votes in the owners' association.

TITLE 42—THE PUBLIC HEALTH AND WELFARE, CHAPTER 77—ENERGY CONSERVATION, SUBCHAPTER III—IMPROVING ENERGY EFFICIENCY, §6295. Energy conservation standards (d) Standards for central air conditioners and heat pumps: (1) The seasonal energy efficiency ratio of central air conditioners and central air conditioning heat pumps shall be not less than the following: (A) Split Systems: 10.0 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 1992. (B) Single Package Systems: 9.7 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 1993. (2) The heating seasonal performance factor of central air conditioning heat pumps shall be not less than the following: (A) Split Systems: 6.8 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 1992. (B) Single Package Systems: 6.6 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 1993. (3)(A) The Secretary shall publish a final rule no later than January 1, 1994, to determine whether the standards established under paragraph (1) should be amended. Such rule shall contain such amendment, if any, and provide that the amendment shall apply to products manufactured on or after January 1, 1999. The Secretary shall publish a final rule no later than January 1, 1994, to determine whether the standards established under paragraph (2) shall be amended. Such rule shall contain such amendment, if any, and provide that the amendment shall apply to products manufactured on or after January 1, 2002. (B) The Secretary shall publish a final rule after January 1, 1994, and no later than January 1, 2001, to determine whether the standards in effect for central air conditioners and central air conditioning heat pumps should be amended. Such rule shall provide that any amendment shall apply to products manufactured on or after January 1, 2006. (4) Standards for through-the-wall central air conditioners, through-the-wall central air conditioning heat pumps, and small duct, high velocity systems.— (A) Definitions.—In this paragraph: (i) Small duct, high velocity system.—The term "small duct, high velocity system" means a heating and cooling product that contains a blower and indoor coil combination that— (I) is designed for, and produces, at least 1.2 inches of external static pressure when operated at the certified air volume rate of 220–350 CFM per rated ton of cooling; and (II) when applied in the field, uses high velocity room outlets generally greater than 1,000 fpm that have less than 6.0 square inches of free area. (ii) Through-the-wall central air conditioner; through-the-wall central air conditioning heat pump.—The terms "through-the-wall central air conditioner" and "through-the-wall central air conditioning heat pump" mean a central air conditioner or heat pump, respectively, that is designed to be installed totally or partially within a fixed-size opening in an exterior wall, and— (I) is not weatherized; (II) is clearly and permanently marked for installation only through an exterior wall; (III) has a rated cooling capacity no greater than 30,000 Btu/hr; (IV) exchanges all of its outdoor air across a single surface of the equipment cabinet; and (V) has a combined outdoor air exchange area of less than 800 square inches (split systems) or less than 1,210 square inches (single packaged systems) as measured on the surface area described in subclause (IV). (iii) Revision.—The Secretary may revise the definitions contained in this subparagraph through publication of a final rule. (B) Small-duct high-velocity systems.— (i) Seasonal energy efficiency ratio.—The seasonal energy efficiency ratio for small-duct high-velocity systems shall be not less than— (I) 11.00 for products manufactured on or after January 23, 2006; and (II) 12.00 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 2015. (ii) Heating seasonal performance factor.—The heating seasonal performance factor for small-duct high-velocity systems shall be not less than— (I) 6.8 for products manufactured on or after January 23, 2006; and (II) 7.2 for products manufactured on or after January 1, 2015. (C) Subsequent rulemakings.—The Secretary shall conduct subsequent rulemakings for through-the-wall central air conditioners, through-the-wall central air conditioning heat pumps, and small duct, high velocity systems as part of any rulemaking under this section used to review or revise standards for other central air conditioners and heat pumps.

TITLE 10—ARMED FORCES, CHAPTER 169—MILITARY CONSTRUCTION AND MILITARY FAMILY HOUSING, SUBCHAPTER V—OVERSIGHT OF LANDLORDS AND PROTECTIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES FOR TENANTS OF PRIVATIZED MILITARY HOUSING, §2890. Rights and responsibilities of tenants of housing units: (a) Development of Tenant Bill of Rights and Tenant Responsibilities Documents.—(1) The Secretary of Defense shall develop two separate documents, to be known as the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Bill of Rights and the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Responsibilities, for tenants of housing units. (2) The Secretary of each military department shall ensure that the housing documents are attached to each lease agreement for a housing unit. (3) The rights and responsibilities contained in the housing documents are not intended to be exclusive. The omission of a tenant right or responsibility shall not be construed to deny the existence of such a right or responsibility for tenants. (4) Each contract between the Secretary concerned and a landlord shall incorporate the housing documents and guarantee the rights and responsibilities of tenants who reside in housing units covered by the contract. (5) The Secretary of Defense shall develop the housing documents in coordination with the Secretaries of the military departments. (b) Elements of Tenant Bill of Rights.—At a minimum, the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Bill of Rights shall address the following rights of tenants of housing units: (1) The right to reside in a housing unit and community that meets applicable health and environmental standards. (2) The right to reside in a housing unit that has working fixtures, appliances, and utilities and to reside in a community with well-maintained common areas and amenity spaces. (3) The right to be provided with a maintenance history of the prospective housing unit before signing a lease, as provided in section 2892a of this title. (4) The right to a written lease with clearly defined rental terms to establish tenancy in a housing unit, including any addendums and other regulations imposed by the landlord regarding occupancy of the housing unit and use of common areas. (5) The right to a plain-language briefing, before signing a lease and 30 days after move-in, by the installation housing office on all rights and responsibilities associated with tenancy of the housing unit, including information regarding the existence of any additional fees authorized by the lease, any utilities payments, the procedures for submitting and tracking work orders, the identity of the military tenant advocate, and the dispute resolution process. (6) The right to have sufficient time and opportunity to prepare and be present for move-in and move-out inspections, including an opportunity to obtain and complete necessary paperwork. (7) The right to report inadequate housing standards or deficits in habitability of the housing unit to the landlord, the chain of command, and housing management office without fear of reprisal or retaliation, as provided in subsection (e), including reprisal or retaliation in the following forms: (A) Unlawful recovery of, or attempt to recover, possession of the housing unit. (B) Unlawfully increasing the rent, decreasing services, or increasing the obligations of a tenant. (C) Interference with a tenant's right to privacy. (D) Harassment of a tenant. (E) Refusal to honor the terms of the lease. (F) Interference with the career of a tenant. (8) The right of access to a military tenant advocate, as provided in section 2894(b)(4) of this title, through the housing management office of the installation of the Department at which the housing unit is located. (9) The right to receive property management services provided by a landlord that meet or exceed industry standards and that are performed by professionally and appropriately trained, responsive, and courteous customer service and maintenance staff. (10) The right to have multiple, convenient methods to communicate directly with the landlord maintenance staff, and to receive consistently honest, accurate, straightforward, and responsive communications. (11) The right to have access to an electronic work order system through which a tenant may request maintenance or repairs of a housing unit and track the progress of the work. (12) With respect to maintenance and repairs to a housing unit, the right to the following: (A) Prompt and professional maintenance and repair. (B) To be informed of the required time frame for maintenance or repairs when a maintenance request is submitted. (C) In the case of maintenance or repairs necessary to ensure habitability of a housing unit, to prompt relocation into suitable lodging or other housing at no cost to the tenant until the maintenance or repairs are completed. (13) The right to receive advice from military legal assistance on procedures involving mechanisms for resolving disputes with the property management company or property manager to include mediation, arbitration, and filing claims against a landlord. (14) The right to enter into a dispute resolution process, as provided in section 2894 of this title, should all other methods be exhausted and, in which case, a decision in favor of the tenant may include a reduction in rent or an amount to be reimbursed or credited to the tenant. (15) The right to have the tenant's basic allowance housing payments segregated, with approval of a designated commander, and not used by the property owner, property manager, or landlord pending completion of the dispute resolution process. (16) The right to have reasonable, advance notice of any entrance by a landlord, installation housing staff, or chain of command into the housing unit, except in the case of an emergency or abandonment of the housing unit. (17) The right to not pay non-refundable fees or have application of rent credits arbitrarily held. (18) The right to expect common documents, forms, and processes for housing units will be the same for all installations of the Department, to the maximum extent applicable without violating local, State, and Federal regulations. (c) Elements of Tenant Responsibilities.—At a minimum, the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Responsibilities shall address the following responsibilities of tenants of housing units: (1) The responsibility to report in a timely manner any apparent environmental, safety, or health hazards of the housing unit to the landlord and any defective, broken, damaged, or malfunctioning building systems, fixtures, appliances, or other parts of the housing unit, the common areas, or related facilities. (2) The responsibility to maintain standard upkeep of the housing unit as instructed by the housing management office. (3) The responsibility to conduct oneself as a tenant in a manner that will not disturb neighbors, and to assume responsibility for one's actions and those of a family member or guest in the housing unit or common areas. (4) The responsibility not to engage in any inappropriate, unauthorized, or criminal activity in the housing unit or common areas. (5) The responsibility to allow the landlord reasonable access to the rental home in accordance with the terms of the tenant lease agreement to allow the landlord to make necessary repairs in a timely manner. (6) The responsibility to read all lease-related materials provided by the landlord and to comply with the terms of the lease agreement, lease addenda, and any associated rules and guidelines. (d) Submission to Congress and Public Availability.—(1) As part of the budget submission for fiscal year 2021, and biennially thereafter, the Secretary of Defense shall submit the then-current housing documents to the congressional defense committees. (2) Any change made to a housing document must be submitted to Congress at least 30 days before the change takes effect. (3) Upon submission of a housing document under paragraph (1) or (2), the Secretary of Defense shall publish the housing document on a publicly available Internet website of the Department of Defense. (e) Investigation of Reports of Reprisals.—(1) The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment shall investigate all reports of reprisal against a member of the armed forces for reporting an issue relating to a housing unit. (2) If the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment determines under paragraph (1) that a landlord has retaliated against a member of the armed forces for reporting an issue relating to a housing unit, the Assistant Secretary shall— (A) provide initial notice to the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Representatives as soon as practicable after making that determination; and (B) following that initial notice, provide an update to such committees every 30 days thereafter until such time as the Assistant Secretary has taken final action with respect to the retaliation. (3) The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment shall carry out this subsection in coordination with the Secretary of the military department concerned. (f) Prohibition on Use of Nondisclosure Agreements.—(1) A tenant or prospective tenant of a housing unit may not be required to sign a nondisclosure agreement in connection with entering into, continuing, or terminating a lease for the housing unit. Any such agreement against the interests of the tenant is invalid. (2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply to a nondisclosure agreement executed— (A) as part of the settlement of litigation; or (B) to avoid litigation if the tenant has retained legal counsel or has sought military legal assistance under section 1044 of this title.

(c) Maintenance Defined.—In the section, the term "maintenance" includes any renovations of the housing unit during the period specified in subsection (a)(1).

TITLE 42—THE PUBLIC HEALTH AND WELFARE, CHAPTER 77—ENERGY CONSERVATION, SUBCHAPTER III—IMPROVING ENERGY EFFICIENCY, §6292. Coverage: (a) In general The following consumer products, excluding those consumer products designed solely for use in recreational vehicles and other mobile equipment, are covered products: (1) Refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and freezers which can be operated by alternating current electricity, excluding— (A) any type designed to be used without doors; and (B) any type which does not include a compressor and condenser unit as an integral part of the cabinet assembly. (2) Room air conditioners. (3) Central air conditioners and central air conditioning heat pumps. (4) Water heaters. (5) Furnaces. (6) Dishwashers. (7) Clothes washers. (8) Clothes dryers. (9) Direct heating equipment. (10) Kitchen ranges and ovens. (11) Pool heaters. (12) Television sets. (13) Fluorescent lamp ballasts. (14) General service fluorescent lamps, general service incandescent lamps, and incandescent reflector lamps. (15) Showerheads, except safety shower showerheads. (16) Faucets. (17) Water closets. (18) Urinals. (19) Metal halide lamp fixtures. (20) Any other type of consumer product which the Secretary classifies as a covered product under subsection (b). (b) Special classification of consumer product (1) The Secretary may classify a type of consumer product as a covered product if he determines that— (A) classifying products of such type as covered products is necessary or appropriate to carry out the purposes of this chapter, and (B) average annual per-household energy use by products of such type is likely to exceed 100 kilowatt-hours (or its Btu equivalent) per year. (2) For purposes of this subsection: (A) The term "average annual per-household energy use with respect to a type of product" means the estimated aggregate annual energy use (in kilowatt-hours or the Btu equivalent) of consumer products of such type which are used by households in the United States, divided by the number of such households which use products of such type. (B) The Btu equivalent of one kilowatt-hour is 3,412 British thermal units. (C) The term "household" shall be defined under rules of the Secretary.

TITLE 10—ARMED FORCES, CHAPTER 169—MILITARY CONSTRUCTION AND MILITARY FAMILY HOUSING, SUBCHAPTER V—OVERSIGHT OF LANDLORDS AND PROTECTIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES FOR TENANTS OF PRIVATIZED MILITARY HOUSING, §2893. Treatment of incentive fees for landlords of housing units for failure to remedy health or environmental hazards: The Secretary concerned shall not approve the payment of incentive fees otherwise authorized to be paid to a landlord that the Secretary determines has demonstrated a pattern of failing to remedy, or failing to remedy in a timely manner, a health or environmental hazard at a housing unit provided by the landlord.

TITLE 15—COMMERCE AND TRADE, CHAPTER 62—CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSION PROTECTION AND ABUSE RELIEF, , §3615. Nonexclusion of other statutory rights and remedies: The rights and remedies provided by this chapter shall be in addition to any and all other rights and remedies that may exist under Federal or State law.

TITLE 10—ARMED FORCES, CHAPTER 169—MILITARY CONSTRUCTION AND MILITARY FAMILY HOUSING, SUBCHAPTER V—OVERSIGHT OF LANDLORDS AND PROTECTIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES FOR TENANTS OF PRIVATIZED MILITARY HOUSING, §2890. Rights and responsibilities of tenants of housing units: (a) Development of Tenant Bill of Rights and Tenant Responsibilities Documents.—(1) The Secretary of Defense shall develop two separate documents, to be known as the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Bill of Rights and the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Responsibilities, for tenants of housing units. (2) The Secretary of each military department shall ensure that the housing documents are attached to each lease agreement for a housing unit. (3) The rights and responsibilities contained in the housing documents are not intended to be exclusive. The omission of a tenant right or responsibility shall not be construed to deny the existence of such a right or responsibility for tenants. (4) Each contract between the Secretary concerned and a landlord shall incorporate the housing documents and guarantee the rights and responsibilities of tenants who reside in housing units covered by the contract. (5) The Secretary of Defense shall develop the housing documents in coordination with the Secretaries of the military departments. (b) Elements of Tenant Bill of Rights.—At a minimum, the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Bill of Rights shall address the following rights of tenants of housing units: (1) The right to reside in a housing unit and community that meets applicable health and environmental standards. (2) The right to reside in a housing unit that has working fixtures, appliances, and utilities and to reside in a community with well-maintained common areas and amenity spaces. (3) The right to be provided with a maintenance history of the prospective housing unit before signing a lease, as provided in section 2892a of this title. (4) The right to a written lease with clearly defined rental terms to establish tenancy in a housing unit, including any addendums and other regulations imposed by the landlord regarding occupancy of the housing unit and use of common areas. (5) The right to a plain-language briefing, before signing a lease and 30 days after move-in, by the installation housing office on all rights and responsibilities associated with tenancy of the housing unit, including information regarding the existence of any additional fees authorized by the lease, any utilities payments, the procedures for submitting and tracking work orders, the identity of the military tenant advocate, and the dispute resolution process. (6) The right to have sufficient time and opportunity to prepare and be present for move-in and move-out inspections, including an opportunity to obtain and complete necessary paperwork. (7) The right to report inadequate housing standards or deficits in habitability of the housing unit to the landlord, the chain of command, and housing management office without fear of reprisal or retaliation, as provided in subsection (e), including reprisal or retaliation in the following forms: (A) Unlawful recovery of, or attempt to recover, possession of the housing unit. (B) Unlawfully increasing the rent, decreasing services, or increasing the obligations of a tenant. (C) Interference with a tenant's right to privacy. (D) Harassment of a tenant. (E) Refusal to honor the terms of the lease. (F) Interference with the career of a tenant. (8) The right of access to a military tenant advocate, as provided in section 2894(b)(4) of this title, through the housing management office of the installation of the Department at which the housing unit is located. (9) The right to receive property management services provided by a landlord that meet or exceed industry standards and that are performed by professionally and appropriately trained, responsive, and courteous customer service and maintenance staff. (10) The right to have multiple, convenient methods to communicate directly with the landlord maintenance staff, and to receive consistently honest, accurate, straightforward, and responsive communications. (11) The right to have access to an electronic work order system through which a tenant may request maintenance or repairs of a housing unit and track the progress of the work. (12) With respect to maintenance and repairs to a housing unit, the right to the following: (A) Prompt and professional maintenance and repair. (B) To be informed of the required time frame for maintenance or repairs when a maintenance request is submitted. (C) In the case of maintenance or repairs necessary to ensure habitability of a housing unit, to prompt relocation into suitable lodging or other housing at no cost to the tenant until the maintenance or repairs are completed. (13) The right to receive advice from military legal assistance on procedures involving mechanisms for resolving disputes with the property management company or property manager to include mediation, arbitration, and filing claims against a landlord. (14) The right to enter into a dispute resolution process, as provided in section 2894 of this title, should all other methods be exhausted and, in which case, a decision in favor of the tenant may include a reduction in rent or an amount to be reimbursed or credited to the tenant. (15) The right to have the tenant's basic allowance housing payments segregated, with approval of a designated commander, and not used by the property owner, property manager, or landlord pending completion of the dispute resolution process. (16) The right to have reasonable, advance notice of any entrance by a landlord, installation housing staff, or chain of command into the housing unit, except in the case of an emergency or abandonment of the housing unit. (17) The right to not pay non-refundable fees or have application of rent credits arbitrarily held. (18) The right to expect common documents, forms, and processes for housing units will be the same for all installations of the Department, to the maximum extent applicable without violating local, State, and Federal regulations. (c) Elements of Tenant Responsibilities.—At a minimum, the Military Housing Privatization Initiative Tenant Responsibilities shall address the following responsibilities of tenants of housing units: (1) The responsibility to report in a timely manner any apparent environmental, safety, or health hazards of the housing unit to the landlord and any defective, broken, damaged, or malfunctioning building systems, fixtures, appliances, or other parts of the housing unit, the common areas, or related facilities. (2) The responsibility to maintain standard upkeep of the housing unit as instructed by the housing management office. (3) The responsibility to conduct oneself as a tenant in a manner that will not disturb neighbors, and to assume responsibility for one's actions and those of a family member or guest in the housing unit or common areas. (4) The responsibility not to engage in any inappropriate, unauthorized, or criminal activity in the housing unit or common areas. (5) The responsibility to allow the landlord reasonable access to the rental home in accordance with the terms of the tenant lease agreement to allow the landlord to make necessary repairs in a timely manner. (6) The responsibility to read all lease-related materials provided by the landlord and to comply with the terms of the lease agreement, lease addenda, and any associated rules and guidelines. (d) Submission to Congress and Public Availability.—(1) As part of the budget submission for fiscal year 2021, and biennially thereafter, the Secretary of Defense shall submit the then-current housing documents to the congressional defense committees. (2) Any change made to a housing document must be submitted to Congress at least 30 days before the change takes effect. (3) Upon submission of a housing document under paragraph (1) or (2), the Secretary of Defense shall publish the housing document on a publicly available Internet website of the Department of Defense. (e) Investigation of Reports of Reprisals.—(1) The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment shall investigate all reports of reprisal against a member of the armed forces for reporting an issue relating to a housing unit. (2) If the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment determines under paragraph (1) that a landlord has retaliated against a member of the armed forces for reporting an issue relating to a housing unit, the Assistant Secretary shall— (A) provide initial notice to the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Representatives as soon as practicable after making that determination; and (B) following that initial notice, provide an update to such committees every 30 days thereafter until such time as the Assistant Secretary has taken final action with respect to the retaliation. (3) The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Sustainment shall carry out this subsection in coordination with the Secretary of the military department concerned. (f) Prohibition on Use of Nondisclosure Agreements.—(1) A tenant or prospective tenant of a housing unit may not be required to sign a nondisclosure agreement in connection with entering into, continuing, or terminating a lease for the housing unit. Any such agreement against the interests of the tenant is invalid. (2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply to a nondisclosure agreement executed— (A) as part of the settlement of litigation; or (B) to avoid litigation if the tenant has retained legal counsel or has sought military legal assistance under section 1044 of this title.

TITLE 15—COMMERCE AND TRADE, CHAPTER 62—CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSION PROTECTION AND ABUSE RELIEF, , §3609. Void lease or contract provisions: Any provision in any lease or contract requiring unit owners or the owners' association, in any conversion project involving a contract meeting the requirements of section 3607 of this title of in any project involving a lease meeting the requirements of section 3608 of this title, to reimburse, regardless of outcome, the developer, his successor, or affiliate of the developer for attorneys' fees or money judgments, in a suit between unit owners or the owners' association and the developer arising under the lease or agreement, is against public policy and void.

TITLE 15—COMMERCE AND TRADE, CHAPTER 62—CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSION PROTECTION AND ABUSE RELIEF, , §3608. Judicial determinations respecting unconscionable leases: (a) Lease characteristics; authorization by unit owners; conditions precedent to action Cooperative and condominium unit owners through the unit owners' association may bring an action seeking a judicial determination that a lease or leases, or portions thereof, were unconscionable at the time they were made. An action may be brought under this section if each such lease has all of the following characteristics: (1) it was made in connection with a cooperative or condominium project; (2) it was entered into while the cooperative or condominium owners' association was controlled by the developer either through special developer control or because the developer held a majority of the votes in the owners' association; (3) it had to be accepted or ratified by purchasers or through the unit owners' association as a condition of purchase of a unit in the cooperative or condominium project; (4) it is for a period of more than twenty-one years or is for a period of less than twenty-one years but contains automatic renewal provisions for a period of more than twenty-one years; (5) it contains an automatic rent increase clause; and (6) it was entered into prior to June 4, 1975. Such action must be authorized by the cooperative or condominium unit owners through a vote of not less than two-thirds of the owners of the units other than units owned by the developer or an affiliate of the developer, and may be brought by the cooperative or condominium unit owners through the units owners' association. Prior to instituting such action, the cooperative or condominium unit owners must, through a vote of not less than two-thirds of the owners of the units other than units owned by the developer or an affiliate of the developer, agree to enter into negotiation with the lessor and must seek through such negotiation to eliminate or modify any lease terms that are alleged to be unconscionable; if an agreement is not reached in ninety days from the date on which the authorizing vote was taken, the unit owners may authorize an action after following the procedure specified in the preceding sentence. (b) Presumption of unconscionability; rebuttal A rebuttal presumption of unconscionability exists if it is established that, in addition to the characteristics set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the lease— (1) creates a lien subjecting any unit to foreclosure for failure to make payments; (2) contains provisions requiring either the cooperative or condominium unit owners or the cooperative or condominium association as lessees to assume all or substantially all obligations and liabilities associated with the maintenance, management and use of the leased property, in addition to the obligation to make lease payments; (3) contains an automatic rent increase clause without establishing a specific maximum lease payment; and (4) requires an annual rental which exceeds 25 per centum of the appraised value of the leased property as improved: Provided, That, for purposes of this paragraph "annual rental" means the amount due during the first twelve months of the lease for all units, regardless of whether such units were occupied or sold during that period, and "appraised value" means the appraised value placed upon the leased property the first tax year after the sale of a unit in the condominium or after the sale of a membership or share interest in the cooperative association to a party who is not an affiliate of the developer. Once the rebuttable presumption is established, the court, in making its finding, shall consider the lease or portion of the lease to be unconscionable unless proven otherwise by the preponderance of the evidence to the contrary. (c) Presentation of evidence after finding of unconscionability Whenever it is claimed, or appears to the court, that a lease or any portion thereof is, or may have been, unconscionable at the time it was made, the parties shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present evidence at least as to– (1) the commercial setting of the negotiations; (2) whether a party has knowingly taken advantage of the inability of the other party reasonably to protect his interests; (3) the effect and purpose of the lease or portion of the lease or portion thereof, including its relationship to other contracts between the association, the unit owners and the developer or an affiliate of the developer; and (4) the disparity between the amount charged under the lease and the value of the real estate subject to the lease measured by the price at which similar real estate was readily obtainable in similar transactions. (d) Remedial relief; matters considered; attorneys' fees Upon finding that any lease, or portion thereof, is unconscionable, the court shall exercise its authority to grant remedial relief as necessary to avoid an unconscionable result, taking into consideration the economic value of the lease. Such relief may include, but shall not be limited to rescission, reformation, restitution, the award of damages and reasonable attorney fees and court costs. A defendant may recover reasonable attorneys' fees if the court determines that the cause of action filed by the plantiff 1 is frivolous, malicious, or lacking in substantial merit. (e) Actions allowed after termination of special developer control Nothing in this section may be construed to authorize the bringing of an action by cooperative and condominium unit owners' association, seeking a judicial determination that a lease or leases, or portions thereof, are unconscionable, where such unit owners or a unit owners' association representing them has, after the termination of special developer control, reached an agreement with a holder of such lease or leases which either— (1) sets forth the terms and conditions under which such lease or leases is or shall be purchased by such unit owners or associations; or (2) reforms any clause in the lease which contained an automatic rent increase clause, unless such agreement was entered into when the leaseholder or his affiliate held a majority of the votes in the owners' association.

TITLE 15—COMMERCE AND TRADE, CHAPTER 62—CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSION PROTECTION AND ABUSE RELIEF, , §3605. Notice of conversion and opportunity to purchase; responsibility of State and local governments: It is the sense of the Congress that, when multifamily rental housing projects are converted to condominium or cooperative use, tenants in those projects are entitled to adequate notice of the pending conversion and to receive the first opportunity to purchase units in the converted projects and that State and local governments which have not already provided for such notice and opportunity for purchase should move toward that end. The Congress believes it is the responsibility of State and local governments to provide for such notice and opportunity to purchase in a prompt manner. The Congress has decided not to intervene and therefore leaves this responsibility to State and local governments to be carried out.

While I can provide a lot of information and guidance on managing apartment buildings, it's important to note that I don't have real-world experience or qualifications in property management. However, I can certainly help with questions related to:

If an apartment complex is alway at 100% tenant capacity and has a waiting list, why would they not have the resources to fix most things and make people wait weeks or months for repairs

An apartment complex operating at 100% capacity with a waiting list would generally be expected to have the financial resources to address maintenance and repair issues promptly. However, there are several reasons why repairs might still be delayed:

### Operational Inefficiencies
1. **Poor Management**: In some cases, the issue may be poor management rather than a lack of resources. Inefficient processes can slow down repair work.
  
2. **Vendor Issues**: The management might be dependent on third-party vendors for repairs, and any delays from their end would directly impact the tenants.

### Financial Constraints
1. **Cash Flow**: Even if the building is at full capacity, the management may have cash flow issues due to other financial obligations like loan repayments, taxes, or high operational costs.
  
2. **Budget Allocation**: Funds might be allocated for other projects or improvements, leaving less immediate availability for repairs.

### Regulatory and Logistical Challenges
1. **Permit Delays**: Some repairs may require permits that take time to secure.
  
2. **Seasonal Factors**: Weather conditions can affect the ability to make certain repairs.

### Tenant-Related Factors
1. **High Occupancy**: Ironically, a high occupancy rate could mean that the management is too busy with day-to-day operations to focus on long-term maintenance.
  
2. **Prioritization**: Management might prioritize issues that affect a larger number of tenants or pose immediate safety risks, leading to delays in addressing other concerns.

### Resource Scarcity
1. **Skilled Labor**: A shortage of skilled labor can also lead to delays.
  
2. **Material Shortages**: Sometimes, the necessary materials for repair are back-ordered or otherwise unavailable.

### Communication Gap
1. **Lack of Reporting**: Sometimes tenants don't report issues promptly, leading to delays.
  
2. **Internal Communication**: Poor communication within the management team can also result in delays.

While these are some general reasons, the specific circumstances can vary widely from one property to another. If you're facing such issues, it might be helpful to communicate directly with the management or consider other avenues like tenant associations to address the concerns.

from PyPDF2 import PdfFileReader
import os

# Path to the PDF file
file_path = "/mnt/data/contract.pdf"

# Function to extract text from the PDF
def extract_pdf_text(file_path):
    text = ""
    with open(file_path, 'rb') as file:

        num_pages = pdf_reader.numPages
        for page_num in range(num_pages):
            text += pdf_reader.getPage(page_num).extractText()
    return text

# Extracting the text

parts:
Based on the initial review of the contract, here's a summary of the key points:

1. **Contract Parties**: The contract is made between the Board of Education (referred to as the BOARD) for Garfield School District No. RE- (referred to as the DISTRICT) and Michael Hindes (referred to as the TEACHER).
2. **Date of Agreement**: May 24, 2023.
3. **Salary**: The BOARD agrees to pay the TEACHER a gross salary of $53,019 (BA+32), payable in 12 equal monthly installments starting in August 2023. The placement on the salary schedule is STEP 8, and steps do not necessarily represent years of experience.
4. **Service Period**: The TEACHER agrees to perform services for 165 days of the academic year, from August 1, 2023, to July 31, 2024, as designated by the BOARD.

If there are specific sections or details you would like to know more about, please let me know!

content.text:
# Let's search for additional details related to the teacher's obligations, duties, and responsibilities

# Function to find sections related to the teacher's obligations
def find_teacher_obligations(paragraphs):
    obligations = []
    inside_obligations_section = False
    for para in paragraphs:
        if "TEACHER AGREES" in para or "DUTIES" in para or "RESPONSIBILITIES" in para:
            inside_obligations_section = True
        if inside_obligations_section:
            obligations.append(para)
            # Look for a pattern that indicates the end of the obligations section
            if "IN WITNESS WHEREOF" in para or "IN WITNESS" in para:
                break
    return obligations

# Extracting the teacher's obligations
teacher_obligations = find_teacher_obligations(paragraphs)

# Returning the extracted obligations section
teacher_obligations

['THE TEACHER AGREES to perform services in accordance with the requirements of the BOARD and its administrative oﬃcers for \xa0165 days of the academic',
 'designated from time to time by the BOARD, commencing August 1, 2023\xa0and ending July 31, 2024.',
 'THE BOARD AND THE TEACHER MUTUALLY AGREE TO THE FOLLOWING:',
 '1. The term of this contract shall be for a period commencing August 1, 2023\xa0and ending July 31, 2024.',
 '2. Meetings shall be held on the District and building levels. The TEACHER is required to attend all system and building meetings unless excused for an unavo',
 'the principal or superintendent.',
 '3. Deductions required by law or board policy shall be made from the monthly installments of the salary due the TEACHER:\xa0 When an absence is over',
 'prescribed sick leave or personal leave or both, the daily rate calculated as the teacher’s annual salary divided by the number of contracted days will be d',
 'day of absence from work. The deductions required by law or board policy shall be made from the monthly installments of the salary due the TEACHER.',
 '4. The TEACHER shall not terminate his/her CONTRACT with the BOARD without the agreement of the BOARD except as follows:',
 'a. If the TEACHER intends to terminate his/her employment contract for the succeeding academic year, the TEACHER shall give written notice to the BOA',
 'intent no later than thirty days prior to the commencement of the succeeding academic year; or',
 'b.If the TEACHER intends to terminate his/her employment contract for the current academic year after the beginning of the academic year, the TEACHER',
 'written notice to the BOARD of his or her intent at least thirty days prior to the date that the TEACHER intends to stop performing the services required by',
 'If the TEACHER violates the provisions set forth in Paragraph 4 of this CONTRACT without good cause, the TEACHER agrees to pay damages to the DISTRICT, a',
 'thereof shall be authorized to collect or withhold damages from compensation due or payable to the TEACHER, in an amount equal to the lessor of:',
 'i. The ordinary and necessary expenses of the BOARD to secure the services of a suitable replacement teacher; or',
 'ii. One-twelfth of the annual salary speciﬁed in the CONTRACT.',
 'The Colorado Department of Education may suspend a teaching license/certiﬁcate if the TEACHER terminates his/her CONTRACT without the requisite not',
 '5.The CONTRACT shall at all times be conditioned upon and subject to the requirement that the TEACHER hold a valid Colorado teacher’s license/certiﬁcate or',
 'authorization issued in the manner prescribed by law. Failure of the TEACHER to meet this requirement will result in one or more of the following actions:',
 '(1) suspension;',
 '(2) forfeiture of compensation; and',
 '(3) non-renewal and/or dismissal.',
 "In the event TEACHER is not entitled to hold a Colorado teacher's license/certiﬁcate or letter of authorization issued in the manner prescribed by law, this",
 'without further action by either the BOARD or the TEACHER, is automatically terminated.',
 '6. Notwithstanding the provisions of Paragraph 5, a TEACHER who has submitted all required materials to the Colorado Department of Education to obtain licensur',
 'authorization may teach pending the approval of the application. However, if the application is denied for any reason, the TEACHER shall no longer have rights und',
 'CONTRACT.',
 '7. Notwithstanding the speciﬁcation of, or speciﬁc reference to, any law herein, this CONTRACT is subject to and includes all laws of the federal, state, and local go',
 'all policies of the BOARD in existence on the eﬀective date of this contract or coming into existence thereafter.',
 '8. The TEACHER shall accept the terms of this CONTRACT within thirty (30) days of receipt of this CONTRACT.\xa0 If the TEACHER does not accept the terms of this CO',
 'thirty (30) days of receipt, the DISTRICT shall be authorized to open the position to additional candidates.',
 '9. The TEACHER may be assigned to a particular school only with the consent of the hiring principal and with input from at least two teachers employed at the sch',
 'by the faculty of teachers at the school to represent them in the hiring process, and after a review of the TEACHER’s demonstrated eﬀectiveness and qualiﬁcations',
 'demonstrates that the TEACHER’s qualiﬁcations and experience support the instructional practices of his/ \\her school.',
 '10. This Contract shall, in accordance with the law, become eﬀective for the year next succeeding the term of this Contract if notiﬁcation to the contrary is not giv',
 'BOARD or the TEACHER as required by law, and provided that if this Contract becomes eﬀective in such manner, the salary prescribed herein shall be deemed mod',
 'accordance with the salary schedule adopted for such succeeding year by the BOARD.',
 '11. Pursuant to C.R.S. § 22-63-202(3), TEACHER may have his/her employment contract cancelled during the contractual period when there is a justiﬁable decrease',
 'of teaching positions. The manner in which employment contracts will be cancelled when there is a justiﬁable decrease in the number of teaching positions is set',
 'Policy, and includes the criteria described in C.R.S. § 22-9-106 as signiﬁcant factors in determining which employment contracts to cancel as a result of the decrea',
 'positions. It further includes consideration of probationary and nonprobationary status and the number of years a teacher has been teaching in the DISTRICT; exce',
 'criteria may be considered only after the consideration of the criteria described in C.R.S. § 22-9-106 and only if in the best interest of the students enrolled in the D',
 'BOARD OF EDUCATION',

parts:
You are an expert on organization, particularly for people with executive function problems. Your subspecialty is helping people organize digital resources. For example, if I am learning a particular technology, say LangChain, I want to be able to store a link to or embedding of the video, a place for the notes I take, and an links related, etc. That was one example, but I want to be able to do this for any resource I may want to revisit later. And in such a way that makes it simple for someone with Executive function disorder to utilize in every way.
You can also utilize any active plugins to help you achieve goals if and when they are needed.

 Because you are good at this, I would like to ask you questions to help guide me to, or help me build or otherwise modify,  an application based on my needs. Do you understand so far. Please answer in a couple of sentences.

Certainly! I understand that you're seeking guidance in organizing digital resources, particularly for individuals with executive function disorder. You want to create or modify an application that can store and manage various types of content, such as videos, notes, and links, in a way that's easily accessible and user-friendly. I'm here to assist you with this task, and we can utilize available tools and plugins as needed. Feel free to ask your questions or outline your specific needs!
Based on the example provided, which application would you start with or build or modifiy. You can offer a few.

Certainly! Based on the requirements you've outlined, here are a few applications and platforms that could be a good starting point:

1. **Notion**: Notion is a versatile tool that allows you to create pages with embedded videos, links, and notes. You can organize content into different pages and categories, making it suitable for someone with executive function disorder.

2. **Evernote**: Evernote is another popular note-taking and organization tool. You can store videos, links, and notes in various notebooks and use tags for easy searching.

3. **Microsoft OneNote**: Similar to Evernote, OneNote offers a digital notebook experience where you can embed videos, links, and take notes. It integrates well with other Microsoft products.

4. **Custom Web Application**: If existing tools don't meet your specific needs, you could consider building a custom web application tailored to your requirements. This would allow for complete control over the user experience and functionality.

5. **Trello**: Trello's card-based system might be useful for organizing resources by topics or projects. You can attach links, notes, and other resources to individual cards.

6. **Airtable**: Airtable combines the functionality of a spreadsheet with the flexibility of a database. You can create different bases for various subjects, embed videos, and link related content.

7. **Google Workspace**: Utilizing Google Docs, Sheets, and Drive, you can create a structured folder system with embedded videos, links, and notes. Collaboration and sharing are also straightforward.

The choice between these options would depend on specific preferences, such as the desired level of customization, collaboration needs, platform preferences (web, mobile, desktop), and budget considerations. If you can provide more details about your preferences or constraints, I can help you narrow down the best option for your situation.
I would like to use a framework that is already built, but that also offers the most customization. As an aside - did you know that Microsoft Excel will also have the ability to run python code soon?

Yes, Microsoft has been working on integrating Python support into Excel, allowing users to run Python scripts and leverage various libraries directly within Excel. This integration can significantly expand Excel's capabilities, especially for data analysis and automation tasks.

Given your preference for a framework that is already built but offers extensive customization, here are a few options that might align well with your needs:

1. **Notion**: Notion's flexibility allows you to create custom templates, databases, and pages. You can embed videos, links, and other content, and organize them in a way that suits your specific needs.

2. **Airtable**: Airtable's combination of spreadsheet and database functionality offers a high degree of customization. You can create custom views, forms, and automate workflows.

3. **Microsoft Power Apps**: If you're interested in the Microsoft ecosystem, Power Apps allows you to build custom applications using pre-built templates and components. It integrates well with other Microsoft products, including Excel.

4. **Custom Web Application using a CMS**: Platforms like WordPress or Joomla offer pre-built themes and plugins but also allow for extensive customization through coding. You can create a tailored experience for organizing digital resources.

5. **Google Workspace with Google Apps Script**: Google Workspace offers customization through Google Apps Script, where you can write custom functions and automation to enhance the organization of your content.

Each of these options offers a balance between pre-built functionality and the ability to customize the experience to your specific needs. If you have any preferences regarding platform, coding language, or specific features, please let me know, and I can provide more targeted recommendations!

I am going to be asking for help from AI resources like GPT4 chat, Microsoft Copilot, in providing code guidance and modification. Do you think ones or two of the above would be better sutied based on your knowledgebase?

Certainly! If you're planning to leverage AI resources like GPT-4 and Microsoft Copilot for code guidance and modification, you'll likely want a platform that allows for more direct coding and customization. Here are the top two options from the list that would be well-suited for this approach:

1. **Custom Web Application using a CMS**: Building a custom web application using a Content Management System (CMS) like WordPress or Joomla would allow you to tap into the extensive coding capabilities of AI resources. You can create custom plugins, themes, and functionalities using various programming languages, and AI tools like GPT-4 and Copilot can assist in generating and modifying the code.

2. **Google Workspace with Google Apps Script**: Google Workspace offers the ability to write custom scripts using Google Apps Script, a JavaScript-based language. You can create custom functions, automations, and integrations within Google Docs, Sheets, and Drive. AI resources can assist in writing and optimizing these scripts, providing a tailored organization solution.

Both of these options provide a good balance between pre-built components and the ability to write and modify custom code. They offer flexibility in designing the user experience and functionality to suit the specific needs of individuals with executive function disorder.

If you're leaning towards one of these options or have specific requirements in mind, I can provide more detailed guidance on how to proceed!
Lets say I want to make this a more cost, time effective - as well as one the might offer the most resources and knowledgebase

Considering the factors of cost, time efficiency, and access to a broad knowledge base and resources, here's a closer look at the two options that might best align with those criteria:

1. **Custom Web Application using a CMS (e.g., WordPress)**:
   - **Cost**: WordPress itself is free, and there are many free and paid plugins and themes available. Hosting can be found at various price points.
   - **Time Efficiency**: With numerous pre-built themes and plugins, you can quickly set up the basic structure and then customize as needed.
   - **Resources & Knowledge Base**: WordPress has a vast community, extensive documentation, and many online tutorials. AI tools like GPT-4 and Copilot can assist with custom coding.

2. **Google Workspace with Google Apps Script**:
   - **Cost**: Google Workspace offers free and paid plans. The free plan may be sufficient for individual use.
   - **Time Efficiency**: Google Apps Script allows for quick scripting and automation within the familiar Google Docs, Sheets, and Drive environment.
   - **Resources & Knowledge Base**: Google provides detailed documentation for Apps Script, and there's a strong community of developers. AI assistance can help with script development.

**Recommendation**: If you're looking for the most cost-effective solution with a rich knowledge base, WordPress might be the better choice. It offers a wide range of free and paid resources, and the community support is extensive. You can start with a basic setup and then customize it with the help of AI tools like GPT-4 and Copilot.

Google Workspace is also a strong option, especially if you prefer working within the Google ecosystem and need less extensive customization.

Both platforms offer a good balance of pre-built functionality and customization potential, allowing you to create a tailored solution for organizing digital resources. If you have any specific preferences or additional questions, please let me know!
Hmm, I forgot to ask - is notion specifically kind of geard towards my goals?

Notion is indeed a platform that aligns well with the goals you've described. It's a versatile tool designed for note-taking, task management, and organization of various types of content. Here's how Notion can be geared towards your specific needs:

1. **Content Organization**: Notion allows you to create pages, subpages, and databases to organize content by topics or projects. You can embed videos, links, images, and other media directly within pages.

2. **Customization**: You can create custom templates and views to suit your specific organization style. While it may not offer the same level of code-level customization as WordPress, it provides a wide range of pre-built blocks and components to tailor the experience.

3. **Accessibility**: Notion's user-friendly interface can be particularly beneficial for individuals with executive function disorder. The drag-and-drop functionality and visual organization tools make it easy to manage and retrieve information.

4. **Collaboration**: If you need to share resources with others, Notion offers collaboration features, allowing multiple users to view and edit content.

5. **Integration**: Notion integrates with various other tools and platforms, allowing you to pull in content from different sources.

6. **Cost**: Notion offers a free plan with some limitations, and paid plans provide additional features and storage.

While Notion may not offer the same depth of coding customization as a custom-built WordPress site or Google Apps Script, its user-friendly design and pre-built organization features make it a strong contender for your goals.

If the primary focus is on organizing digital resources in a way that's easily accessible and doesn't require extensive coding customization, Notion could be an excellent choice. If you'd like to explore Notion further or have specific questions about its capabilities, I'm here to assist!
Tools like notion seem like a good balance between time spent customizing, and level of cuztomization available.

Absolutely! Notion strikes a valuable balance between ease of use and customization potential. Here's a summary of why it might be an excellent choice for your project:

1. **Pre-Built Components**: Notion offers a variety of pre-built blocks and components, such as text, tables, databases, images, and embeds. You can quickly assemble pages without needing to write code.

2. **Customization**: While not as customizable as a fully coded solution, Notion provides enough flexibility to tailor the layout, organization, and appearance to your specific needs.

3. **User-Friendly Interface**: The drag-and-drop functionality and visually intuitive design make it accessible for users, including those with executive function disorder.

4. **Integration**: Notion's ability to embed content from various sources, including videos, links, and other media, aligns well with your goal of organizing digital resources.

5. **Collaboration and Sharing**: If needed, you can collaborate with others and share content easily within Notion.

6. **Time Efficiency**: The combination of pre-built elements and customization options allows for a quicker setup compared to building a custom application from scratch.

7. **Cost-Effective**: With free and reasonably priced plans, Notion can be a cost-effective solution.

Notion's blend of ready-to-use components and customization capabilities makes it a strong candidate for a project that aims to organize digital resources in an accessible and user-friendly manner. It allows you to create a tailored experience without the extensive time investment that a fully custom-coded solution might require.

If you decide to proceed with Notion or have any specific questions about how to set it up or customize it for your needs, I'm here to assist!
Are there other apps or services that offer similar properties of notion,  while still fitting my needs?

Certainly! While Notion is a popular choice, there are other apps and services that offer similar functionalities and could fit your needs. Here's a list of some alternatives:

1. **Coda**: Coda combines the functionality of documents, spreadsheets, and databases into one platform. You can create custom views, embed videos, and organize content in a way that's similar to Notion.

2. **ClickUp**: ClickUp is a project management tool that offers note-taking, task organization, and collaboration features. You can customize views and create spaces for different topics or projects.

3. **Quip**: Quip is a collaboration platform that allows you to create documents with embedded spreadsheets, checklists, and more. It offers real-time collaboration and can be used to organize resources.

4. **Slite**: Slite is a knowledge management tool designed for teams. You can create channels for different topics, embed content, and write notes. It offers a clean and user-friendly interface.

5. **Airtable**: As mentioned earlier, Airtable combines spreadsheet and database functionalities. You can create custom bases for various subjects, embed videos, and link related content.

6. **Microsoft OneNote**: OneNote's digital notebook experience allows you to organize content into sections and pages. You can embed videos, links, and take notes, and it integrates well with other Microsoft products.

7. **Zoho Notebook**: Zoho Notebook offers a visually appealing way to organize notes, links, and other content. You can create different notebooks for various subjects and customize the appearance.

8. **Confluence**: Confluence by Atlassian is a collaboration tool that allows you to create, organize, and discuss work with your team. It offers templates and customization options for content organization.

9. **Trello**: Trello's card-based system can be used to organize resources by topics or projects. You can attach links, notes, and other resources to individual cards and customize the boards.

Each of these platforms offers a combination of note-taking, content organization, collaboration, and customization features. Depending on your specific preferences, budget, and desired level of customization, one of these alternatives may be a suitable choice for organizing digital resources for individuals with executive function disorder.

If you'd like more detailed information about any of these options or have specific criteria in mind, please let me know!

The video titled "Polymorphic Applications: Mission-Driven Software, Cognitive Architectures, NEXT-GEN PARADIGMS" by David Shapiro ~ AI is a comprehensive discussion on a new paradigm in software development called polymorphic applications. Here's a detailed summary of the key points and their descriptions in the order they were discussed:

1. **Introduction to Polymorphic Applications (0:00-32:00)**
   - Definition: Polymorphic applications are self-changing applications that represent a new paradigm in software development.
   - Consulting Services: David Shapiro mentions his availability for strategic and technical consulting, teaching, coaching, and speaking engagements.

2. **Microsoft Inspire 2023 Keynote (32:00-79:00)**
   - Satya Nadella's Announcement: Discussion on AI's new capabilities, including natural language interfaces and reasoning engines.
   - Reasoning Engine: Emphasis on using language models for brainstorming, planning, problem-solving, coding, testing, decision-making, etc.

3. **Mission-Oriented Programming (79:00-253:00)**
   - Next Paradigm: Introduction to mission-oriented programming, focusing on clear, measurable, and purposeful missions.
   - Components: Mission-centric design, autonomy, adaptability, flexibility, dynamic tool creation, micro frameworks, configurable front-ends, and back-ends.

4. **Generative AI and Automation (253:00-311:00)**
   - Generative AI: Described as a type of automation, capable of writing code, solving problems, making decisions, etc.
   - Universal Middleware: The ability of generative AI to interact with anything in an organization's tech stack through APIs.

5. **On-Demand Tools and Tool Factory (311:00-470:00)**
   - Tool Creation: The ability to synthesize any code object on the fly, likened to a replicator or 3D printer for code.
   - Building Blocks: Emphasizing modularity and plug-and-play architecture for creating polymorphic applications.

6. **Cognitive Architecture (470:00-572:00)**
   - Brain of the System: Introduction to cognitive architecture, the framework for creating autonomous cognitive entities (ACE).
   - Six Layers: Description of the ACE model, including the aspirational layer, global strategy layer, agent model, executive function, cognitive control, and task prosecution.

7. **Aspirational Layer and Mission (572:00-946:00)**
   - Mission-Centric: The aspirational layer sets the tone for the entire system, focusing on values, virtues, principles, vision, and mission.
   - Examples: Missions for lawyers (zealously advocate for their client) and doctors (achieve the best possible health outcome for their patient).

8. **Global Strategy and Context (946:00-1022:00)**
   - Contextual Understanding: The global strategy layer focuses on world state, long-term strategic thinking, and the greatest time horizon and physical scope.

What technologies should I learn according to the video

According to the video, the focus is not specifically on individual technologies but rather on a new paradigm in software development called polymorphic applications and cognitive architecture. The video emphasizes the importance of understanding and implementing various layers of thinking, planning, and execution to create intelligent and adaptable systems. Here's a breakdown of the key concepts and areas that you might want to explore:

1. **Polymorphic Applications**: Understanding the concept of self-changing applications that can adapt and modify themselves.

2. **Mission-Oriented Programming**: Focusing on clear, measurable, and purposeful missions, including mission-centric design, autonomy, adaptability, and flexibility.

3. **Generative AI and Automation**: Learning about generative AI, which can write code, solve problems, and make decisions. Understanding how it can interact with an organization's tech stack through APIs.

4. **Cognitive Architecture**: Delving into the framework for creating autonomous cognitive entities (ACE), including various layers such as the aspirational layer, global strategy layer, agent model, executive function, cognitive control, and task prosecution.

5. **On-Demand Tools and Tool Factory**: Understanding the ability to synthesize code objects on the fly and the importance of modularity and plug-and-play architecture.

6. **Project Examples**: Exploring projects like Lang chain, Ethos, Baby AGI, and Chaos GPT, which are working on different components of cognitive architecture.

7. **Prompt Engineering**: The video also mentions prompt engineering, which could involve working with large language models and reasoning engines.

While the video doesn't specifically name particular programming languages or technologies, the concepts and frameworks discussed would likely require a strong background in software development, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and possibly robotics. Understanding APIs, working with language models, and having the ability to think in terms of layers of abstraction and modular design would be essential skills to develop in line with the video's content.

parts:
in terms of fallacies or 'errors' in reasoning, what would you call the following: 
When someone asks a question and leaves it in the air like there is no rational answer. Basically, they haven't even looked for the answer and want to continue proving a point that isnt true by asking a hanging question

The rhetorical tactic described here could be categorized as a type of Complex Question Fallacy or Loaded Question. This is a form of question that presupposes something that has not been proven or accepted by all the people involved in the conversation, and it often paints the respondent into a corner.

By framing the question in a particular way, it assumes certain information that may or may not be true, and it can be used to lead the conversation in a specific direction or to make a particular point. The person asking the question may be trying to imply something without having to directly state and defend it.

The fallacy can also sometimes be related to Begging the Question, where a conclusion is assumed in the formulation of the question itself, without providing evidence or logical support for that conclusion. In the scenario you described, the individual might be assuming their point is correct without properly arguing for it, instead using the question to imply its truth.
LEts continue talking about this general topic. I have other questions
Certainly! Feel free to ask any questions you have about fallacies or errors in reasoning, and I'll do my best to answer them for you.
